Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Nanoscale Printing and Machining using Electron Beams in Liquids

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nearly all high-throughput nanomanufacturing processes require the replication of master templates. As a result, three barriers to manufacturability demand new solutions: (1) rapid prototyping before committing to a production template, (2) repair of template errors and defects both before and during production, and (3) product debugging before committing to revised templates. Locally adding ("printing") and subtracting ("machining") materials using a focused electron-beam could meet these needs if the available materials, purity, and throughput were not limited by the associated gas-phase reactants. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award investigates a change from gas to liquid reactants in order to expand the range of processes and materials available and dramatically improve purity and throughput. These advances would enhance efficiency at multiple points in the product cycle for nanomanufactured systems, and thus benefit U.S. industry and society. The award involves an industry partner to accelerate the transition from laboratory research to industrial implementation. The multidisciplinary nature (electrical, chemical, and materials science and engineering) of the work provides a remarkable training opportunity for undergraduate and graduate participants, while educational and outreach efforts involving K-12 students further broaden its impact.

The award advances knowledge in the primary field of electron-beam induced processing by elucidating the physical and chemical mechanisms involved in liquid-based processes and deepening understanding of the factors controlling resolution, material purity, and throughput. The effort will advance understanding of radiation- and electro-chemistry in nanoscale volumes near liquid-solid interfaces and fluid dynamics in reduced pressure environments. This knowledge is relevant to fields as diverse as in-situ electron microscopy, electron-beam lithography, and radiation induced chemical and biochemical processes. The technical objectives are to (1) relate process parameters to figures of merit by comparing deposition and etching experiments to Monte Carlo and finite element simulations; (2) understand how to control thin liquid films in partial vacuums using in-situ liquid injection, microfluidic structures, and surfactant additives; and (3) evaluate processes for two immediate nanomanufacturing applications: nanoelectronic circuit edit and plasmonic device prototyping.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nearly all high-throughput nanomanufacturing processes require the replication of master templates.  As a result, three barriers to manufacturability demand new solutions:  (1) rapid prototyping before committing to a production template, (2) repair of template errors and defects both before and during production, and (3) product debugging before committing to revised templates.  Locally adding ("printing") and subtracting ("machining") materials using a focused electron-beam could meet these needs if the available materials, purity, and throughput were not limited by the associated gas-phase reactants.  This project investigated a change from gas to liquid reactants in order to expand the range of processes and materials available and dramatically improve purity and throughput.  These advances would enhance efficiency at multiple points in the product cycle for nanomanufactured systems, and thus benefit U.S. industry and society.  The project involved industry partners to accelerate the transition from laboratory research to industrial implementation.  The multidisciplinary nature of the work provided a remarkable training opportunity for high-school, undergraduate, and graduate participants, while educational and outreach efforts impacted K-12 students and their families. 

The intellectual merit of the research rested on enhancing understanding of the physical and chemical mechanisms involved in electron-beam material processing in liquids and establishing the impact of these mechanisms on resolution, material purity, and throughput.  A key outcome of the project was understanding the electron-beam induced deposition of copper, a critical material for integrated circuit manufacturing, and silver, a critical material for nanophotonics.  The work provided evidence for a radiation-chemical mechanism of deposition and established conditions under which <100 nm copper structures could be printed with purity and throughput dramatically exceeding that of gas-phase copper precursors.  Silver has been especially challenging to deposit from gas-phase precursors, but this project showed that high-resolution, high-purity silver structures could be printed with high efficiency from solutions of silver nitrate on various substrates.

A second key outcome was understanding the electron-beam induced etching of copper, a key integrated circuit material, and nickel, an important material for lithographic masks, imprint templates, and nanomagnetic device.  This project showed that focused electron beams in sulfuric acid solutions can etch copper with high resolution, throughput, and selectivity to other materials.  Accurate numerical models of the etch process were developed that accounted for a variety of physical and chemical mechanisms.  Finally, high-resolution, electron-beam induced etching of nickel was demonstrated in sulfuric acid solutions, but the process chemistry was found to differ significantly from that of copper. 

Understanding how to manipulate thin liquid films in the partial vacuum environment near the electron beam was also a key aspect of the project's intellectual merit.  Work with an industrial partner established that liquids could be injected at micron scales so that printing and machining could take place in targeted areas of interest.  Developing new techniques to measure liquid film thickness in partial vacuum and to inject liquid into microfluidic structures proved important for controlling and understanding the deposition and etch processes.  These results also have broader applicability to in-situ microscopy.

Both the intellectual merit and the broader impact of the project were supported by testing the new printing and machining processes in two application areas:  nanoelectronic circuit editing and rapid prototyping of nanophotonic structures.  With regard to circuit edit, the project demonstrated that copper interconnects could be printed in a desired region with conductivity near bulk copper.  This represented a dramatic improvement over copper deposition from gas-phase precursors.  Likewise, work with a second industry partner showed that interconnects fabricated by standard semiconductor manufacturing could be modified locally with the new process.  Finally, the project demonstrated that silver nanostructures of sufficient resolution and purity could be printed to support localized surface-plasmon resonances.  Such structures are important for microscopy, biochemical sensing, and emerging lens and filter systems.

The project had broader impacts in educating a nanomanufacturing work force at the graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 levels.  Four graduate students, three undergraduates, and one high school student received extensive nanotechnology related training through this effort.  In addition, a focused group of middle school students benefited from extended demonstrations and tutorials.  The ability to print arbitrary nanostructures in familiar materials in real time makes this technology an excellent educational vehicle for K-12 students and their families.  This was born out through well-received demonstrations during National Engineers Week.  In addition to traditional journal and conference dissemination of the research, it was also presented to a broad educational and industrial audience as part of the unique KY Nanotechnology and Additive Manufacturing Symposium.  This symposium, affiliated with the NSF National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network, brings together traditionally disparate communities in additive manufacturing and nanofabrication.  Finally, the collaboration with two industrial partners further ensured broader impact through accelerated technology transfer and industry exposure to the research.


Last Modified: 01/02/2020
Modified by: J. Todd Hastings
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nearly all high-throughput nanomanufacturing processes require the replication of master templates. As a result, three barriers to manufacturability demand new solutions: (1) rapid prototyping before committing to a production template, (2) repair of template errors and defects both before and during production, and (3) product debugging before committing to revised templates. Locally adding ("printing") and subtracting ("machining") materials using a focused electron-beam could meet these needs if the available materials, purity, and throughput were not limited by the associated gas-phase reactants. This project investigated a change from gas to liquid reactants in order to expand the range of processes and materials available and dramatically improve purity and throughput. These advances would enhance efficiency at multiple points in the product cycle for nanomanufactured systems, and thus benefit U.S. industry and society. The project involved industry partners to accelerate the transition from laboratory research to industrial implementation. The multidisciplinary nature of the work provided a remarkable training opportunity for high-school, undergraduate, and graduate participants, while educational and outreach efforts impacted K-12 students and their families. The intellectual merit of the research rested on enhancing understanding of the physical and chemical mechanisms involved in electron-beam material processing in liquids and establishing the impact of these mechanisms on resolution, material purity, and throughput. A key outcome of the project was understanding the electron-beam induced deposition of copper, a critical material for integrated circuit manufacturing, and silver, a critical material for nanophotonics. The work provided evidence for a radiation-chemical mechanism of deposition and established conditions under which <100 nm copper structures could be printed with purity and throughput dramatically exceeding that of gas-phase copper precursors. Silver has been especially challenging to deposit from gas-phase precursors, but this project showed that high-resolution, high-purity silver structures could be printed with high efficiency from solutions of silver nitrate on various substrates. A second key outcome was understanding the electron-beam induced etching of copper, a key integrated circuit material, and nickel, an important material for lithographic masks, imprint templates, and nanomagnetic device. This project showed that focused electron beams in sulfuric acid solutions can etch copper with high resolution, throughput, and selectivity to other materials. Accurate numerical models of the etch process were developed that accounted for a variety of physical and chemical mechanisms. Finally, high-resolution, electron-beam induced etching of nickel was demonstrated in sulfuric acid solutions, but the process chemistry was found to differ significantly from that of copper. Understanding how to manipulate thin liquid films in the partial vacuum environment near the electron beam was also a key aspect of the project's intellectual merit. Work with an industrial partner established that liquids could be injected at micron scales so that printing and machining could take place in targeted areas of interest. Developing new techniques to measure liquid film thickness in partial vacuum and to inject liquid into microfluidic structures proved important for controlling and understanding the deposition and etch processes. These results also have broader applicability to in-situ microscopy. Both the intellectual merit and the broader impact of the project were supported by testing the new printing and machining processes in two application areas: nanoelectronic circuit editing and rapid prototyping of nanophotonic structures. With regard to circuit edit, the project demonstrated that copper interconnects could be printed in a desired region with conductivity near bulk copper. This represented a dramatic improvement over copper deposition from gas-phase precursors. Likewise, work with a second industry partner showed that interconnects fabricated by standard semiconductor manufacturing could be modified locally with the new process. Finally, the project demonstrated that silver nanostructures of sufficient resolution and purity could be printed to support localized surface-plasmon resonances. Such structures are important for microscopy, biochemical sensing, and emerging lens and filter systems. The project had broader impacts in educating a nanomanufacturing work force at the graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 levels. Four graduate students, three undergraduates, and one high school student received extensive nanotechnology related training through this effort. In addition, a focused group of middle school students benefited from extended demonstrations and tutorials. The ability to print arbitrary nanostructures in familiar materials in real time makes this technology an excellent educational vehicle for K-12 students and their families. This was born out through well-received demonstrations during National Engineers Week. In addition to traditional journal and conference dissemination of the research, it was also presented to a broad educational and industrial audience as part of the unique KY Nanotechnology and Additive Manufacturing Symposium. This symposium, affiliated with the NSF National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network, brings together traditionally disparate communities in additive manufacturing and nanofabrication. Finally, the collaboration with two industrial partners further ensured broader impact through accelerated technology transfer and industry exposure to the research.
